reasoning: 1. Circle of Competence: Microsoft is a complex software and cloud business. I’m a coot who owns Coca-Cola because I understand fizzy drinks and consumer habits, not hyper-scalable enterprise software. I’d rather stay in my knitting. 2. Moat: Yes, Windows, Office 365 and Azure give some pricing power, but the moat looks inconsistent – ROE only averaged 9.2% and never topped 15% in recent periods. 3. Management & Capital Allocation: They’ve issued stock recently, keeping dividends modest. That dilutes owners and signals they may not see better uses for cash. 4. Financial Health & Consistency: Debt-to-equity sits near 1.0, ROIC is weak at 4.6%, and earnings growth has been choppy (6.7% over ten periods). Not the fortress I look for. 5. Valuation: With an intrinsic value around $145,000 (after a 15% haircut) versus the eye-popping market cap of $2.5 trillion, the margin of safety is negative 94%. I don’t buy businesses at founded losses of safety. 6. Long-Term Prospects & Red Flags: Cloud growth is strong, but rapid tech shifts and competition from AWS and Google keep me uneasy. A durable advantage must withstand decades, and I can’t forecast software trends that long. 7. Opportunity Cost: I’d rather own See’s Candies, Coca-Cola or BNSF – businesses I understand, with real moats and sensible valuations. When I don’t understand a business or can’t buy it at a reasonable price, I step aside. This is a “no” for me.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 9.2%; High debt to equity ratio of 1.0; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 6.7% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 76.1%) indicate pricing power moat; High performance stability (92.8%) suggests strong competitive moat

book_value_analysis.details: Consistent book value per share growth (Buffett's favorite metric)

management_analysis.details: Recent common stock issuance (potential dilution); No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (5.2%, 5y), Stage 2 (2.6%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
